newsitem.title: INDIA: India's truck owners launch nationwide strike.
newsitem.headline: India's truck owners launch nationwide strike.

text.p: The owners of more than two million trucks pulled their vehicles off India's roads on Tuesday in protest over a proposed service tax and higher insurance premiums, transport officials said.
Booking and delivery at nearly 60,000 transport companies across the country came to a standstill, S.P. Singh, a spokesman for All India Motor Transport Congress (AIMTC), told Reuters.
The nationwide strike started at midnight March 31, he said.
The congress represents owners of about two million heavy trucks, one million light and medium-weight trucks and some 60,000 booking and delivery companies.
"About 2.2 million trucks have gone on strike," Singh said, adding that talks between government officials and the AIMTC had so far failed to break the deadlock.
Further talks were planned for later on Tuesday.
The AIMTC objected to a five percent service tax on road transport which Finance Minister P. Chidambaram proposed in the federal budget for the 1997/98 (April-March) financial year.
It also denounced a decision by state-owned insurance companies which the transport congress said would raise insurance premiums between 300 and 400 percent.
"Nearly 60 percent of goods are carried by roads. Hence any move to stop transport will adversely affect movement of goods and traffic," said a spokesman for a northern Indian chamber of commerce.

"The strike should be deferred. Even if the truckers have some grievances it should be addressed when there is a stable government," the spokesman for Punjab, Haryana, Delhi Chambers of Commerce and Industry (PHDCCI) said.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's 10-month-old minority government is facing a political crisis after its key ally, the Congress party, withdrew support on Sunday.
Deve Gowda has been given until April 11 by President Shankar Dayal Sharma to face a confidence vote in the Lok Sabha, or lower house of the parliament.
Deliveries of aviation fuel to airports could also be affected by the national truck strike, another AIMTC official said.

He said dock workers at Nava Shiva, the port for Bombay, would refuse to load or unload ships. The strike started a day earlier than first planned, at midnight on Sunday, in the western state of Maharashtra.
Aviation fuel is delivered by private carriers or government-owned tankers from companies such as Indian Oil Corporation.
"There will not be any immediate impact as inventories of aviation fuel are usually there for three, four days. We will not stop the government carriers from supplying," Singh said.
The AIMTC had two rounds of talks with government officials on Monday.
"We had two rounds of government (talks) which lasted for five to six hours but failed to yield any result," Singh said.
Truck owners said the ball was in the government's court and hoped officials would resolve the impasse soon.
Singh said the last time truck owners went on strike was in 1993, which lasted for 13 days.
